heroSection.message: unravelling the wonders of nature through chemistry.

about.heading: Dr. Pradip Kr. Tarafdar
about.bio: Dr. Tarafdar studied BSc at Ramakrishna Mission Vidyamandira, Belur. He passed MSc at University of Calcutta having specialization in Organic Chemistry. Later, he was inclined to biological processes and pursued PhD at School of Chemistry, University of Hyderabad under the supervision of Prof. Musti J. Swamy. During postdoctoral research, he worked with Prof. Barry Lentz (former President, Biophysical Society) at University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, USA and as an Alexander von Humboldt Fellow with Prof. Reinhard Jahn at Max-Planck Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Göttingen, Germany.
education: B.Sc. (Chemistry Honors), Ramakrishna Mission Vidyamandira, Belur, University of Calcutta, India, 2002.
M.Sc. (Chemistry, Organic Chemistry Specialization), University of Calcutta, India, 2004.
Ph.D. (Bioorganic and Biophysical Chemistry), University of Hyderabad, India, 2010. || Guide - Prof. Musti J. Swamy
Post Doc (University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.) || Guide - Prof. Barry Lentz
Post Doc (Max-Planck Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Göttingen, Germany.) || Guide - Prof. Reinhard Jahn
positions: CSIR-JRF, School of Chemistry, University of Hyderabad, India, (2004-2006).
CSIR-SRF, School of Chemistry, University of Hyderabad, India, (2006-2009).
NIH Post-doctoral Fellow, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, USA (2010-2012).
Alexander von Humboldt Fellow, Max-Planck Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Göttingen, Germany (2013-2014).
DST-Inspire Faculty, Saha Institute of Nuclear Physics, Kolkata (2014-15).
Assistant Professor, Indian Institute of Science Education and Research Kolkata (2015-2021).
Associate Professor, Indian Institute of Science Education and Research Kolkata (2021-present).
awards&disnt: NIH Post-doctoral Fellow, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, USA (2010-2012).
Alexander von Humboldt Fellow, Max-Planck Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Göttingen, Germany (2013-2014).

contact.heading: Contact Us
contact.joinUsStatement: We look for talented and dedicated students to pursue research in the field of Bioorganic Chemistry. Interested students may write to Dr. Pradip Kumar Tarafdar.
address: Lab : M353, 3rd floor, DCS, Research complex, IISER Kolkata
Office : Room no 321, office corridor 3rd floor, DCS, Research complex IISER Kolkata

researchTopics.title: Antivirals and antibacterials
researchTopics.discription: The emergence of new viruses and their potential mutations obstruct effective vaccine development and possible cure. For example, the recent coronavirus infection already killed ~ 250000 people in India, influenza kills ~ 290000-650000 people annually, dengue infected ~ 4.7 million people last year. An effective fusion inhibitor may emerge as an effective broad-spectrum antiviral to neutralize the infection from harmful enveloped viruses as membrane fusion is extremely important to the life cycle of these viruses. We aim to learn from mother nature to develop an effective fusion inhibitor. Our peptide inhibitors were shown to protect cells from lethal type 1 influenza virus and mouse coronavirus viral challenge as a ‘broad spectrum’ antiviral agent. In addition, we develop polymer-based anti-bacterials.

researchTopics.title: Membrane Transport inspired Organic Methodology in water
researchTopics.discription: Membrane trafficking is a core biological process and using this nature directs the correct cargo in a guided manner i.e. to the right place at the right time. We envisioned whether the membrane trafficking can be utilized to promote proximity and localization of reactants to design a small molecule enzyme mimic. We report for the first time that positively charged micro heterogeneous vehicles loaded with substrate could be trafficked suitably at the site of the reaction to promote the localization and proximity of the reactants.  The guided vehicular delivery coupled with electrolysis overcomes the entropic barrier related to the proximity of the reactants and allows the hydrolysis of non-activated esters, electron transfer reactions at physiological pH.

researchTopics.title: Amyloid Fibril Inhibitors
researchTopics.discription: There are currently more than twenty identified amyloid-associated disorders, including common neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD), Parkinson’s disease, and prion disorders. Unfortunately, the molecular-level understanding of the pathways, including kinetic barrier leading to these debilitating proteopathies remains obscure. We found that the hydrophobic and H-bonding anchoring sites of porphyrin-based molecules inhibit the self-aggregation of amyloidogenic proteins via strong binding with protein units. Our molecules with hydrogen bonding anchoring sites at both sides, was identified as a potent inhibitor to insulin, amyloid-beta and lysozyme fibrillation.

activities.discription: Glimpses of a last get-together with two of our brilliant BS-MS students - Soumajit and Bishvanwesha, as they head towards pursuing PhD. in the US. Both of them joined our lab in their 3rd year in early 2020 and now after successfully completing their masters' they are set to achieve higher goals. We wish them all the best for their future endaveours! Have a bright future and wonderful life ahead.

As we prepare to move onto the next phase of our journey, the memories keep us bound to the wonderful people who stood beside us! Here's a glimpse of Avijit reminiscing and acknowledging the wonderful time spent as a family in Memface lab.
Our oldest (and wisest XD) student Avijit successfully completes his pre-submission seminar. Years of dedicated research and hardwork culimates to this. So proud of you!

Our group just got bigger and better! With the official joining of Sanu and Debosmita, we are looking forward to attaining greater heights than ever (obviously without reducing the fun time together :P). Welcome to both of you.

Glimpses of the first home party upon institute re-opening after the tiring and prolonged covid enforced shut down. Looks like we got a new entertainer in Soumajit with his guitar and singing. A truly lovely evening marked by collaborative cooking, engaging discussions and some lovely music! A real treat after a long time!
